user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_file_close_:
```c
static int lfs_file_close_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
#ifndef LFS_READONLY
    int err = lfs_file_sync_(lfs, file);
#else
    int err = 0;
#endif

    // remove from list of mdirs
    lfs_mlist_remove(lfs, (struct lfs_mlist*)file);

    // clean up memory
    if (!file->cfg->buffer) {
        lfs_free(file->cache.buffer);
    }

    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_file_close_:
static int lfs_file_sync_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_file_t *file) {
    if (file->flags & LFS_F_ERRED) {
        // it's not safe to do anything if our file errored
        return 0;
    }

    int err = lfs_file_flush(lfs, file);
    if (err) {
        file->flags |= LFS_F_ERRED;
        return err;
    }


    if ((file->flags & LFS_F_DIRTY) &&
            !lfs_pair_isnull(file->m.pair)) {
        // before we commit metadata, we need sync the disk to make sure
        // data writes don't complete after metadata writes
        if (!(file->flags & LFS_F_INLINE)) {
            err = lfs_bd_sync(lfs, &lfs->pcache, &lfs->rcache, false);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }
        }

        // update dir entry
        uint16_t type;
        const void *buffer;
        lfs_size_t size;
        struct lfs_ctz ctz;
        if (file->flags & LFS_F_INLINE) {
            // inline the whole file
            type = LFS_TYPE_INLINESTRUCT;
            buffer = file->cache.buffer;
            size = file->ctz.size;
        } else {
            // update the ctz reference
            type = LFS_TYPE_CTZSTRUCT;
            // copy ctz so alloc will work during a relocate
            ctz = file->ctz;
            lfs_ctz_tole32(&ctz);
            buffer = &ctz;
            size = sizeof(ctz);
        }

        // commit file data and attributes
        err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &file->m, LFS_MKATTRS(
                {LFS_MKTAG(type, file->id, size), buffer},
                {LFS_MKTAG(LFS_FROM_USERATTRS, file->id,
                    file->cfg->attr_count), file->cfg->attrs}));
        if (err) {
            file->flags |= LFS_F_ERRED;
            return err;
        }

        file->flags &= ~LFS_F_DIRTY;
    }

    return 0;
}
...
static void lfs_mlist_remove(lfs_t *lfs, struct lfs_mlist *mlist) {
    for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &lfs->mlist; *p; p = &(*p)->next) {
        if (*p == mlist) {
            *p = (*p)->next;
            break;
        }
    }
}
...
typedef struct lfs_file {
    struct lfs_file *next;
    uint16_t id;
    uint8_t type;
    lfs_mdir_t m;

    struct lfs_ctz {
        lfs_block_t head;
        lfs_size_t size;
    } ctz;

    uint32_t flags;
    lfs_off_t pos;
    lfs_block_t block;
    lfs_off_t off;
    lfs_cache_t cache;

    const struct lfs_file_config *cfg;
} lfs_file_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I found no code fragments that modify a function parameter variable itself (i.e., no assignment to the pointer parameters ‘lfs’ or ‘file’). Rule 17.8 forbids modifying the parameter (the pointer value); it allows modifying the object pointed to. In the provided code: • lfs_file_close_ does not assign to ‘lfs’ or ‘file’; it only calls other functions and accesses/modifies fields of *file (e.g., freeing file->cache.buffer), which is permitted. • lfs_mlist_remove receives a pointer named mlist but never assigns to that parameter; it updates list links via *p = (*p)->next which modifies the list objects reachable from the lfs parameter (allowed), not the parameter pointer. • lfs_file_sync_ modifies fields of *file (file->flags, file->ctz) and uses lfs-> members; these are modifications of the pointed-to objects and are allowed by the rule. • The cast (struct lfs_mlist*)file does not reassign the parameter. Therefore there are no fragments that appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 and no further investigation of parameter assignments is necessary.
